comment_data.body: While it is false in the case of toxme, that's not really relevant to tox. If I start a website that saves passwords but I only support http, that doesn't' make [name of popular web service] less secure. -- It's only my password saving service that's insecure.

comment_data.body: somewhat: The specific use case that the original author planned to use toxcore personally does effectively guarantee forward secrecy. While in actuality, there's no such promise made, merely; it'll probably work.

+    messenger;

comment_data.body: Here I disagree. If a website uses super secure backends to store the data, but has doors wide open in the process of information transfer, then I would not call this service/website secure. I could call components of it secure. So it should still be mentioned prominently in various places, that using toxme is not providing the same level of security as using a tox id.

comment_data.body:
re drawing the line: make clear that basic working of tox is secure (tox id, etc.) but that if you rely on any third party-service, toxme being just an expample - it does not give the same security guarantees. I know, this is not about a website advertizing tox, and that it should be clear for a developer, but better be clear than face criticism for being insecure. All ways to use a service count, and what at the end matters is the user's security. User does not care if part xyz is what he used was secure, when his data leaked it leake, no matter which part leaked it. So anything that is supported should either be save or have a warning about potentially bing unsave. If a provider of any webservice says they hash all passwords, but receive them in plain text via http, then this service cannot claim to be secure. The line there would be that the transfer is part of the service. But if the user writes down his password on a noted next to his computer, this is not part of the service, and this insecurity is caused by the user.
That's how I see it.
